												I won't tell you if you'll like it or not. I'll tell you what you're getting so you can decide for yourself.Here's the major points most other reviews are missing:1. This is a sidescrolling RTS, not a platforming Terraria/Starbound clone.You do not modify your surroundings. There is no major recipe-based crafting. You don't WASD to move your hero; you drag a box around the group of units you want to control and right-click to perform move/attack/skill commands. This will not scratch that 2D sandbox-world itch.2. If you don't like the deck-building process of your favorite trading card game, you won't likely enjoy this game.You choose/enhance the characters you want, then their classes, then their tech tree bonuses, and then finally their gear and abilities before every "level." This is literally half the game, and it's akin to the deck-building portion of your typical TCG. You then pit this "deck" of characters against a random series of enemy-filled rooms and hopefully find pride in the outcome of your well thought out preparations. This inevitably results in a couple dozen more items (read: "new cards for your deck") with which you rinse and repeat endlessly. How this comparison is being missed until now is beyond me, but it's an incredibly important aspect to understand before you sink your teeth into this game.3. Your first couple hours can be hard to enjoy as your decisions/mistakes will not feel meaningful/consequential.You won't start off with much of anything to do beyond selecting all of your units, right-clicking bad guys, and waiting for everything to die. Fortunately, this isn't the case after your first hour or two. You'll also eventually realize the significance of your resources as soon as you run out of one for the first time (e.g., the currency for shopping, the currency for cloning items and reviving, the currency for your tech tree, or the fuel for exploring new levels). Much more importantly, however, you'll discover (on your own, after the tutorial) that the difficulty of each individual "level" can be scaled through the roof as you see fit; there's no need to bore yourself to death versus enemies that require no thought or effort to defeat. And before you ask, scaling the difficulty up does reward you with better loot drops accordingly, so it's a satisfying choice instead of an arbitrary, self-imposed challenge.4. The amount of content is appreciably greater than most "loot 'em ups."Each class feels uniquely important with a wide variety of sub-specialties to choose from within each class. The active and passive buffs and unlocks you'll have to pick from in the tech tree are mostly all interesting. The random item modifiers on your gear range from the typical +stats, resistances, and status immunities to auto-casting unique spells on weapon reload and ensuring a chance to drop consumables on kill. The art for each world feels rich and engrossing. The enemies you'll encounter are varied enough in behavior, ability, and art that you likely won't think to complain. The random NPCs and quest-givers you'll come across frequently have distinct personalities and charm. There's also a decently-lengthed story-focused quest line, procedurally generated side missions, unexpected random encounters, and your typical market fare (buying and selling from stores, shipyards, blackmarkets, etc). 												Pixel Privateers is in no way a bad game, however there are issues with the gameplay and mechanics that let it down as a whole.Disclaimer: I do not hate this game, I actually quite like it, however I feel that 87% is too high for what this game offers so I'm writing a review explaining my opinion.Pros:+ART: Some of the pixel artwork is pretty lovely, the bases and planets are well detailed and beautiful+WORLD: The world and concept is nice, it stays pretty consistant with races and characters; There are cyborgs in this galaxy that have spread out over countless worlds, as well as a race of bio-monsters that want to turn all genetics into their fleshy masses of DNA, and you're trying to get technology from these worlds for The Company. It gets a bit more advanced later on, but stays at the 'passable' stages and never quite overtakes a lush and consistent sci-fi world like say FTL+LOOT: There is plenty of Borderlands-esque loot; I also like that what look you equip determines their class. Every character has 4 slots and you can spend ages just fitting out your guys after a couple missions of loot.+TECH TREES: I like the researching mechanic in the game, despite its simplicity; You just pick up items and they gain research points over time which you can spend on identifying rares or upgrading a crew-wide research tree.Cons:-BUGS: Could not use an elevator and had to force quit the game. Melee units would not attack certain enemies. Units would sometimes walk back and forth in the middle of combat and doing nothing. Hold position button does nothing. Right clicking to attack enemies as they beam into your ship causes all your units to move to it. Can cheese losing situations by quitting the game and everybody gets max halth again. Game breaking framerate at some boss levels. Sold all my inventory, went back to crew tab and it was still there. That's just a handful of the ones I remember right now.-SIMPLICITY: At the start, when you have 2-3 guys, combat requires thought, and pausing it with the spacebar. However, late game is just a grind of taking your 8 man squad of level 26 guys with guns, selecting them all, and right clicking every enemy in order until they're all dead. This plays into my next point...-NO AUTO ATTACK!?: Yours guys do not auto attack. This is a huge, huge problem and reduces incentive for using strategic attacks, and encourages just using your entire squad to attack one enemy. Say there's a group of three enemies; if they kill the first one, if you do nothing they just won't attack; they would all die before attacking by themself. This seems to also include turrets and drones. This can be fixed, I'm sure, but it's a massive gaping problem that encourages zerg rushing, and unfortunately the game is still very possible using that strategy. Another problem with this is there is LITERALLY A HOLD-POSITION BUTTON that says "Will attack enemies in range" and it just doesn't! They still suffer from the same auto-attack issue.-VARIETY: There are plenty of enemy types in this game, don't get me wrong. But, as a whole, there seems to be 3 races: Two robots and a zerg-equivalent. The problem with this is that, using the zerg rush tactic explained above, they all have the same tactic to kill them, select everyone, right click, zerg rush, win. Very rarely do you need to, for example, move your guys out of enemy fire, get on either side of an enemy to flank, use abilities to stun or put in stasis.... Coz you just right click them all to death. To put it into perspective, I used exactly the same tactic on the bosses, including final boss; right click it to death and occasionally right click a spawned minion. The healers heal automatically so I don't need to do anything.-SHIP INVASIONS: When you're travelling around on the map, random events can occur, normally being attacked by an enemy ship. This is, without a doubt, the worst (purposely programmed) part of the game. You just walk around your ship, wait for enemies to teleport into the room, and kill them. There's no 'defense' part about it whatsoever, it's just a boring time waster that gives barely any reward. The devs must know this because there's a perk at the start AND a research tree item to lower the chance of it happening.-STORY: The 'story' itself is pretty generic; however my issue is that it drags on for so long. There is absolutely no reason this game needs to go for 12-18 hours. You'll enjoy your first 6 for sure, but the lack of variety in the late game leads to tedium and total boredom. Even the regular missions become a total chore (which you need to do a certain amount of to unlock more missions) of just blasting through 90% of a map. And, I'll put it here; two of the boss stages featured game-breaking framerate issues (The second robot boss and the first zerg boss) where my game slowed down to 10 fps. This is a pixel game. I have no idea why this happens but for lower end computers I can imagine those levels would be a total pain.-PIXEL PIRATES: You've probably realized by now that this game is developed by the same people who made Pixel pirates. Whilst not a bad game in itself, that game lacked a real driving force to grind through its countless bugs and far-too-long campaign. Privateers is better, by a long way (At least I only discovered a handful of bugs with this and not a thousand game breaking ones), it benefits from a more direct approach. However, the late stages feel like a chore with collecting 5 Macguffins, and then in true No Man's Sky fashion, the game just ends and starts you again with a different map but the same characters. If you have never played Pixel Pirates and you like the idea, you will definitely enjoy this game more than Pirates, but understand these games are not perfect. It's a meal-priced RPG strategy-lite.CONCLUSION:If you came to this game looking for an exploration game, you should try Starbound.If you came to this game looking for a space roguelike, you should try FTL.If you came to this game looking for a strategy game, try.... I dunno, Battle Brothers is pretty good lol.And if you came because "It's by the Terraria guys!" no, it's just published by them. If you are really digging for a good strategy-building space game, then you should 100% definitely try Rimworld instead.6/10: Game is functional but lacks a lot of stuff that makes a strategy-roguelike engaging for longer periods of time.

												tldr: Pixel Privateers is a Squad Based Tactical RPG “Loot ‘Em Up", you control your squad, visit planets, accept missions, fight enemies, level up, fight bosses.+ Loot tiers and tons of loot.+ Always have a fresh feeling while exploring new planets.+ The astonishing pixelart and the music.+ The storyline/lore about the universe and the humor in the dialogues. + Replayability.+ You 'll find yourserlf craving for "one more planet"- There is always room for improvement especially in the very high levels after finishing the storyline.- You might have to deactivate some settings in the options menu if you own a lower end pc/laptop.- You can skip the tutorial but i wouldn't suggest that, you will miss some features that aren't that obvious otherwise.Being among my most played games on steam i'm very confident to recommend this to anyone who is reading this, interested in what he/she sees in the store page. If you wish to read more about how much content there is, what are some key features and my disclaimer continue reading down below.* Playing the game for the first time in normal mode will take you around 20 hours to complete the storyline but the content can keep you busy for many many more.* Multiplayer is up to 4 people, drop in-drop out style, no servers needed.* You can play normal mode or hardcore mode (your whole crew dies = your save file is done)* You can choose your own difficulty in each planet, each one determines the loot quality you'll get.* 5 classes (Vanguard, Marine, Engineer, Scout and Medic) and you can have 1-8 crew members in your squad both for SP and MP.* Each class has their own abilities and also equipable tools which give you different extra abilities for each class.* 9 loot tiers (poor, common, uncommon, exceptional, rare, epic, artifact, legendary, ultimate).* Huge pool of modifiers meaning that your armor, weapons and tools can have some crazy stats added to them.* Many different planet types. Each planet is unique with randomly generated "dungeons"/rooms you have to clear.* Tons of different/unique enemies from each faction. * The universe is finite with around 300-400 planets in it,but there is NG+ too (continue playing with the same squad and gear in a different universe)* Click to attack a single enemy, you can control one by one your crew members or all of them as squad, you can also pause the action in single player.* The game scales everything to you, you will have a different experience fighting at level 1 than at level 10 or 20 for example.* You can buy new ships and add modules to them which give you extra perks (for example your ship can carry more crew members).I hope this huge wall of text helped you decide if that's the game for you or not.Disclaimer: I was one of the lucky ones to be accepted in a closed beta over a year and a half ago. I got to enjoy the game throughout almost half of its developement and as a thank you to them, i as many others dedicated many hours making sure that the game will be the polised title you see today. And yes i got the game for free but it didn't change my opinion.

												A great concept, rough around the edges.    I am writing this as a family man with very limited time to sit down and immerse myself in games. As such my leanings lately (2015 - 2017) are games that follow this criteria (This is not exhaustive but I hope I can convey the gist)1. Inexpensive but with good value. pricing is subjective, but some games need the base game plus 4+ extra DLC in order to 'enjoy proper', I avoid this more often than not.2. Playable for minutes or hours but feels like I'm making progress no matter what. Open World games usually suceed at this, MMORPGS however not so much. When I can play in long bursts, Its because I'm enjoying the game not because I need to in order to, Save or progress. Interesting aside, I love Soulsborn because progress happens everytime you play, even if it is minute. 3.  Ability to Pause for long periods while I chase my toddler down, cook, run an errand etc4. Production Value, Mobile games and free to play usually lack this; there are exceptions like Warframe. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The above mentioned list demonstrates my situation fairly clearly I hope, I need a game that I can play within my hectic life, a game with quality that doesn't demand 4 hours at a time minimum in order to feel like that game session was worth it. Pixel Privateers fits this bill for me perfectly. It's playable in 8 hour bursts of for a quick 20 minute mission. So for my lifestyle and if you are in a similar situation to me, it's a candidate for Daddy's 45 minute breathing time until Saul, Underwood and Bojack come back... -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------As a game does it hold up??I love the idea. It's a little bit of a few genres I am endeared wtih. I love the ability to name my squaddies. My kids love hearing the stories of their little pixels saving the group or wiping out the bad guys with that new flamethrower. The gameplay is fine, but I find that larger squads require a bit micro management that I am simply not good at. There is a quality of life issue I have; My squad won't attack unless I order them to. I've had situations where I'm in a fight and my squad fights the boss, once the boss dies or explodes into a horde, I have to manually target the lesser enemies, which are small that feels like an extra step that isn't fun. The larger engagements are usually fine, but my squad not defending itself because I can't find the enemy or I'm looking up from my screen for real life issues. It's nothing major but is apparent.The style and presentation are good, Tongue in cheek full of references and I must say, almost obligatory nowadays. There is also alot of downtime between missions as you consider resources, fuel and weapon loadouts. I love it, each mission yields a surplus of items that you can sell for credits, which are used for ship upgrades, having more control on the loot you have via being abe to purchase from the shop or buying more squaddies. The other options are like the Kanai cube/Hordordic cube from Diablo to reroll 4 item types, rarity for different items or rarities and finally broken down into matter, which is used for teleporting your squad to missions and reviving the little buggers should you die on normal mode. All in all, this game is fun, engaging and with its own flaws (That could be patched out easily.... please turn on auto fire!) Thank you for your time in reading this

												A fun loot-gathering game with a ton of options regarding party-comp and character customization. Two characters of the same class need not be the same stat/skill wise, and there are a ton of weapons to choose from (there are no class/weapon restrictions). As an example, my medic uses hammers and gets bonus heals for every attack he does. He beats enemies in the face and heals while he does so.Gameplay is interesting, albeit a bit uninvolved in the early game. Planets tend to be varied and there are a few different objectives that you may receive upon landing. Gameplay consists of the loop of: Prepare party -> go to planet and get loot -> go to galaxy map -> prepare party -> repeatIt's simple, but it's addicting and the varied loot keeps me coming back for more. I recommend it if you're into games like Diablo, Path of Exile, Grim Dawn, etc.My biggest gripe, aside from a lack of truly varied objectives, is that controlling five characters is tedious, thus leading me to leave most of them on auto while I control my tank and engineer.  I would like to see more viability for having fewer than five characters in a party (three would be my sweet spot between interesting gameplay/party comp and reasonable micro-management). The game does allow you to pause mid-combat to issue orders, which helps with this; think Baldur's Gate or Pillars of Eternity.Overall, the game is quite fun and offers a really addicting loot-loop that I think will be enticing to many players.

												The game has really nice graphics and style.Alas, it totally falls short on the gameplay and tactics aspect :- the gameplay fails to evolve.You keep encountering random and unpredictable difficulty spikes which, once combat is engaged, results pretty much in the death of your squad and are unescapable : imagine you do a mission and suddenly open a door with enemies overwhelming you  in a few seconds.You can pause and all, you have a few powers to try to mitigate what is happening ; but it is like using a glass of water in a forest fire. The scale of what the players can do is ridiculously limited, shooting, and healing are for most automatic on timers things.You imagine when yhou finally build a crew quarter having more squaddies will let you manage things more finely.But no : having more squaddies means the game just drastically scales the game difficulty.Everything is scaled in a geometric manner : resarch is the same.This effectively negates any evolution in the players actions and gameplay and pretty much kills any sense of progress beyond the WOW loot colors your soldiers equip. A very poor evolution.- The tactics aspect is just for show.So, your engineer can deploy a turret. Which you will do over and over again.The medics have a pain suppression ability and a heal both on a timer.The whole thing is just crazyly underwhelming. The available player actions are more of a sideshow to the automatic heal/attacks of the squaddies. They are something to keep you busy while pretending there is some control over what is happening.But this control is just too much a fringe thing. The 2d aspect of the game combined with the lack of control of the action just gives the illusion of control and turns frustrating when you discover this does not get any better while levelling up.It really is too bad.Some inspiration over the gameplay could have turned Pixel Privateers intop a must have.But as it turns out, the gameplay choices made are just uninspired, leaving a semi automatic pilot loot management game (which there is WAAYYYY too much, seriously, another reason not to have too many recruits as it quicly turns hellishly tedious), with no true control from the player over the situation it randomly encounters.You will still have a good time discovering stuff in the game.But know it does not get any better than the hope the player gets of what could be at the beginning. The game sadly fails to deliver in what it actually becomes.A real shame that is.

												70/100, not worth $15 yet.The game has potential, but seriously tapers off after a dozen hours.Wait for later patches, see my suggestions. The game feels unfinished despite 1 major 5-part quest chain. ======== Pros/Cons ========+ Great artwork+ Loot-a-holic drops, 8 tiers (grey, dark green, light green, blue, purp, red, orange, and teal)+ Nice skilltree, multi tiers, upgrading both characters and your ship.+ Great rooms system on ships, has more potential later on.+ Love having multiple units, each class has 3 play style options based on their class relic.+ Ability to add difficulty to missions for better chance at loot drops.+ There's a few rerferences to other games, which is a trip.    (Apparently there's a cube recipe for a cow level? I would love to see a wiki for unique recipes)= Music is alright. Not blown away, but not hating it either. Chill, sorta ambient at times. = Matter / Fuel become almost useless over time with high-tier Research Point upgrade.= There's a nice number of planets to check out, but see my notes on level scaling. However, there are a ton of small things that just snowball into a poor experience.These will effect your gameplay, I guarantee it. - Major memory leaks / fps drops: I'm running a moderate+ system (i5 with a 1070 GPU)  I'll drop from 150 frames down to 20 over the course of one map. That needs to be addressed. - No Auto Attack + Hold Commands don't work: I would make more use of tactical pauses, but it's just better to set a 2x4 basic team formation (Vanguard tanks up front, Marines 2nd, Healers 3rd, and Scout/Eng in the back) and just focus fire on one monster at a time. Your units will just sit there and eat damage if you don't do something about it. Keep a finger on Q, you'll be babysitting that key.- Automatic level scaling: I love leveling to zone, and the bosses should reflect that progression as a milemarker.Nothing feels better than grinding hard, swooping solid gear then smashing a boss into next week. (It should be a 15-25-35-45-55, Final 65+ kinda deal.) This way, If I want a hard battle, I can throw on the modifiers. Instead, Give yourself 15+ mins (not kidding) to chip away at each boss and micromanage their timed minion summons. Bosses aren't a challenge as much as they are obnoxius. Every planet auto scales to you, so there's no benefit or need to travel far out to find the right zone.  The level scaling seriously kills the sense of progression in this game. - "Company Quests" are just cheap low-tier item / fuel / matter grabs. Take your pick of the three: Save prisoners, research rooms, collect random drops. Rinse. Repeat.- They need to change the color on their final item tier. Top tier items blend in a little too easily. Try black/red/silver striped boxes or somethin' different. - Multiplayer is a nice feature, but it needs a ton of work. I had some luck with playing LAN, but I have heard horror stories for those not playing locally. - Endgame after the warp: I watched my brother play past the final boss, but... there's... nothing.  No endgame quest trigger, no special company quests, no unique planets. Did we miss something?  Why include it if there is nothing but a replay of the same game under the guise of an "alternative universe?"Edit: I made it to the "alternative universe" to see it for myself.... uhhh. Wut. ======= Final Verdict ========70/100The games an alright time sink for now, and with some much needed fixes, it could be worth 15+ bucks.They have a great idea, and some great mechanics already in place.Problem is it's lacking some basic features and endgame content. It still has gameplay killing bugs.Either wait for it to go for less than $6-7 on a sale, or wait until 1.0.2 or much later is released.This game was... finished, but not really, you know?======== Dev Suggestions ========- Fix Auto Attack / Hold Commands- Chef Zakarian made a great point about the game having an RTS feel, but not having a intelligent/behavior autoattack system. I linked his review below:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198041699470/recommended/342640/- Remove Level Scaling. It's killing your game.- Address Memory Leaks + FPS Drop. - Please add a convenient to access loot filter. Once you hit 10k Matter, you're really  just looking for Purple's or higher to do cube rolling. Things to add?- Add more quest variants: "Timed" Explore/Kill, Multiplanet Escort Missions, Maybe a "clear infection/wipe out mutiple hives" Maybe a "Distress Beacon, check out this ship" quest. Hell, I would love a "Help fix a warp gate" quest to help create waypoints for far exploring. - Endgame: Perhaps Legendary Class Relic quests, Maybe a rare merchant quest leading to a get upgradeable ship rooms, making matter/fuel useful again.  Introduce Minor/Major sockets add-ons allowing us to tweak with Purple or lesser items. - Play with random encounters: Let me decide to pick up those hitcherhikers that always become Punks invading my ship. Currently they are more of a headache then "oh wow, this could be neat". - Add "warp gates" that we can reach from the outposts, or allow us to save warp locations. - Add "home base" near the first wormhole, where we can store items, maybe have NPCs chill?- Play with your cube crafting system, it's an awesome little thing to gamble/reroll, but you could do some end game customization with it. A recipe tracker tab on the box would be nice.- Trading in multiplayer, it would be nice to have an item/resource economy to encourage dedicated MP. As a side rant, I have put the game down twice trying to get to the 5th boss because I have to fly about 400+ fuels distance (no, I'm not kidding) Why are 4 major bosses within 30 fuel of eachother and this one is so far out?Those interruptions are now the sole the bane of my existence in your game.I wrote this review rather than deal with the trip to the 5th boss.

My point of view is also only from a Normal mode point of view may be different in Hardcore mode.-First impressions-I booted up the game and saw this beutiful screen. It was running pretty smooth. I'm even playing this game on a laptop that is so old, it want turn on without being plugged in. The tutorial was had some humor and went really well, though it could go a bit more indepth on the stats. The only problem was the menu screens. Everybody complains that it is way to much. I find that it is very well organised for something that could have been really bad. The problem with it, is the background stars. It lagged my computer to an unplayable fps. Luckily, you can turn off the stars, but it will take away the blue coloring along with it, leaving a boring black screen behind them. The desert planets are also extremely laggy. There is no option that can fix this. This also makes the surveying missions near impossible, but still luckily are.-Gameplay-The gameplay is very simple, but fun. You request some missions, go to a planet, kill the enemies, loot your surroundings, fisish the mission, and get your sweet reward. The planets are easy on a normal setting, but you can set a different difficulty at any point of going to that planet. The one time I changed a planets difficulty to 10% more enemy health, I was unable to beat it. I did change it back to normal mode, but this one room was impossible to get pass at my current point. Selecting your crew is easy. You can press q to select all, you can select a crew member's icon, or you can select them the same you way you would select a computer application. The abilities are useful but most of the most useful, take hit streaks. Hit steaks are easy to get but this causes the auto-tactical mode option, which tactical is where you can pause mid-game and plan what you are going to do next, to ultimatly become some what useless until 1-2 seconds into battle. Tactical mode is really useful but keep forgetting to use it, which can mean death, if death was a common threat. Tactical mode is also REALLY useful for items. When you need to set a trap for an enemy, use tactical mode. When you need to heal, use tactical mode.-Mechanics for items and training-Out side of battling, you have the menus. I will be honest, you may be looking at these for a while, but unlike everybody says, it is NOT as long as the gameplay on the planets are. This may be true in the begining of the game, but it can change after a few hours. The stats, training as it is called in the game, aren't explained in-game. If you hover over them with your mouse, it will become clear to you quickly. It is like video editing and some forms of computer programming. You can't make sense of it at first, but you will quickly. Items are the same way. You are given a lot of loot and you will be switching items a ton. I actually really liked this whole looking through the items thing for one reason. You have to plan who gets what. You can't give one guy the best gear and everybody else the hand-me-downs. You will have to think, which I love. When I saw that the game had weapon modifiers in its description, I was thinking Terraria modifiers. These are the same idea, but they don't feel like the are. I very rarely give them a second thought.-Mechanics for crew-Changing the subject to the crew, you have up to five. If you get six, the game makes you feel like a jerk, and FORCES you to disintegrate the extra passenger. This isn't Pixel Piracy, where it would make some since to do so. You are the good guys in this game. Anyway, If one of your crew happens to die in battle, to things could happen. 1: The rest of your team will die, which causes you leave the surface. This works 80% of the time for some reason, so you may have to press "esc" and go to the main menu. Don't worry, you want lose any progress. You will thin have to reconstruct crew, which uses matter. Matter is also a rescource that I saw somebody say was annoying and hard to come by. unless you are dying every ten seconds, you want be running out. 2: You some how survived and can retrive while still on planet. While you're not in combat, you can double click his Icon and he will be reconstructed with the price being only matter. To ubtain matter. get read of some usless items and/or choice it as a reward. You can clone a crew member but I would imagine that it isn't the most useful in Normal mode.-Mechanics for your spaceship-This is the shortest of the mechanics. You can extend and costumize your ship, but it isn't as I've grand as something like building it. I could be wrong though since I am yet to get to a ship dock. What can say about it though is that it will help you in the long run. Flying your ship is not like star wars anything like that. I have never played Pixel Piracy, but from what I have seen it, It may be similar to it, but more important and fleshed out. If the Pixel Piracy's traveling was bugged out, I can comfirm that Privateers, is not bugged and pretty interesting. Moving your spaceship will cost fuel. This fuel can only be obtained in market places for high prices low quantity or by choicing it as a reward. I have not had problems with fuel but you will have to keep a very close eye on it. I don't now what will happen if you run out, but there is a distress signal button to save your buns. I just have a feeling that it isn't the cheap.-The conclusion-This game is very well done and polished. I thought I saw a bug once in the game but even that wasn't true. I just didn't pay attention to my surroundings. It may lag with the stars and the desert planets may be worse when it comes to fps, but nothing else is bad. The gameplay pulls you in. The mechanics perfectly balanced. I would recommend this everybody who likes this type of game. Everyone except one. If you have a slow, laggy computer that doesn't play many games well, AVOID THIS GAME! The game is very good and you should give it a go but make sure you know your computer can handle it. Test it on your computer, and if it lags extremly badly on the lowest of setting, pull out a refund. The game is the most demanding game I have.Re-Logic and Quadro Delta, if you are reading this, Thank you for making such an awesome game.-Update-I have finally gotten futher into ship mechanics. You can buy an new ship for high price... unless you have been saving the whole game, like I have. You can easily change the the rooms by clicking the green gear and selecting the room you want it to be. You must have a ship module to do so, which aren't the cheapest things in the world. You can also add in turrents/traps, but two conditions must be true.1: You have a ship turrent/trap. 2: You must have that room changed from default. It is simple as that.

Like, it was right on the cusp of making you say 'This is great!', but there are just too many niggling issues that make you wand to punch a hole through your monitor?That's how I feel about Pixel Privateers.Do not get me wrong, this is by no means a 'bad' game. I didn't realize this at first, so I ended up with this rather confusing situation where I was running around with an almost dead engineer as the rest of the team just stared at him, all the while some monster was trying to eat his face...3. Clutter, clutter, everywhere. The idea of a looter is to collect loot, I know this. But, I feel, there is such a thing as too much loot, especially if it's boring. In my admittedly short time of playing, I didn't find a single interesting weapon or piece of armor... Nothing but slightly improved stats, and higher grade loot needs to be identified before you can use it, which means spending more time in menus. Oh, and any fuel that you pick up isn't automatically added to your tank, you are forced to convert it from a menu... And inventory space is extremely limited early on.4. Matter and Fuel, the most boring, but important things ever. Both of these resources are extremely important, and for the time I played, my entire time was sitting there worrying if I had enough of both. Without fuel, you ain't going nowhere, and without matter, you can't do missions, clone dead troopers, nothin'... So, I spent of my game staring at menus, feeding these two resources the majority of my loot.5. Trying to be tactical is a hassle. Each crewmember, depending on what kind of tool their wielding, has a small action bar with some useful abilities on it. These can be critical to mission success and survival, especially in difficult missions... So why do they make it so damned hard to use them? In order to use a skill, you must first select the appropriate crewmember with your mouse, then click on the skill. Doesn't sound too difficult, but in the thick of a fight it can damned near impossible to click on the correct tiny pixel outline to deploy the right ability.If a few of these problems were fixed, I would have no problem recommending this game, but in its current state, I'd say give it a pass unless the premise really captures your interest.

												I bought this on a whim because it is published by Re-Logic, the team that made Terraria. They've garnered enough goodwill from me to grab anything with their name attached to it. I'd never heard of the developer Quadro Delta but Re-Logic vouching for them was enough for me to take the risk sight unseen.That said, I am absolutely loving the game right now. It's really scratching the itch that I've had for a loot-based game lately. It's a side scrolling, "dungeon" crawling, squad-based, loot grinder. You get up to 8 characters in a team, and run across the surfaces of worlds clearing out the baddies and grabbing piles of loot. At the start I thought there was a possibility that the combat would feel shallow, but as I've progressed through the game and unlocked more skills and tech, the difficulty has really picked up. First, I love the contextual queues for using abilities popping up over squad members in trouble. Each character has around 5 abilities with a variety of effects. That seemed pretty overwhelming for how fast combat moves, but when characters hit low health or have certain status effects, the relevant abilities from all of the squad pop up as action buttons above that character. For example: Someone drops below 50% health, the medic's abilities, the mercenary's heal, and the scout's smoke bomb pop up as abilities to cast at that target. It really streamlines combat to the point that you don't have to frequently pause it and queue up abilities.Second, the loot is incredibly varied. I have started to get a bit of loot fatigue. It is beneficial to pick up every single piece and disintegrate it for "matter" which is used for a variety of things, but there is just so much of it sometimes that it gets to be a bit much. I've started to only identify and manage purple-quality and higher loot. You also eventually find a combining cube (think Diablo 2 Heraldric Cube) that lets you do some re-rolling of items and stats.Third, the worlds all seem varied enough for the 8 or so hours I've played so far. There have been a few occasions of things feeling a little same-y, but the random generation of NPCs and such has helped to diminish that. I've also stumbled across a few interactable elements that end up spawning waves of enemies and give great loot. That has been nice.So far, what I have played feels like a full game. I get the feeling, though, that as I play I'm going to continue finding new elements and content that will add to the game. I've not had the opportunity to build or upgrade my ship yet. I've not had a boarding party show up while in flight. There are things I know I haven't encountered but already feel satisfied with the amount of content available.If you enjoy looking through loot drops, min/maxing stats, squad combat, and mostly-funny dialogue, you should be happy with this. Especially considering the price of entry.

												Negatives:* Numbers and reading overload* Massive amounts of "logistics" between bouts of action* Extremely limited variety of worlds and missions* UI is too clumsy and pacing is too fast for effective tacticsPositives:* Fun art style, music, and humor* Easy to learn game, effective tutorial if you want itInitially it looks like this is going to be a massive game with deep customization possibilities and character progression and suchforth and so on... but really it just gets very repetitive very quickly because there's only a handful of art sets and objectives to draw from.  Privateers tries to mix it up with a story but so far it feels very basic. There's some occasional random encounters which are cute, but ultimately the uniqueness only lasts a few seconds and then you're back into the same "Go there, collect 5 of that" missions you were already doing. It's a game that makes a fabulous first impression but then realize it's got a plethora of issues as you invest more time.A typical mission involves 10 minutes carefully analyzing your loot trying to make sure that your entire team is equipped as well as possible, assigning skill points, and reading about research.  I really hope you like comparing pages of small numbers. Then you deploy to the planet, and it's a few minutes of rolling your mob of guns from left to right (sometimes right to left) and enemies falling over in front of you. You pick up all the junk that was dropped, then it's back to the ship for some more loot analysis.While "kill, loot, kill more, loot more" is indeed the core premise of games like Diablo or Borderlands, the big difference here is that Privateers basically doesn't require you to actually do anything subtle or fancy or skillful to get through. Which is just as well because you have an entire squad of people that you're trying to control, constantly getting stacked on top of eachother and no really good way to check the tactical situation. It's very much a case of building the best horde you can and throwing it at the enemy horde, and maybe getting slightly interested if the enemy horde doesn't die instantly. There's only two fights I can remember where I really had to stop and try to figure out what was going on, and there was no leadup or story or anything involved; just random bad luck getting some enemies that synergized well with eachother, and the resulting ball of chaos because precise placement of units or seeing individual attacks and effects is impossible.Privateers basically reached a fork in the design road and tried to go both ways at once. If you want a deep squad tactical experience, you need to give the player more precision and more tools. Things like a grid system for movement, zones of control, cover, a combat log, or even going turn based.  Versus, if you want a light fast action experience, then you need to cut 3/4 of the "logistics" phase between missions and give players more immediate control over fewer and more interactive characters.  In its current form Privateers either has way too much prep time for its barely-controllable storm of bullets, or way too little player control for its tactical ambitions.

												I was looking forward to this game for many, many months following its announcement. The time I did spend playing Pixel Piracy, I really enjoyed it. So I thought, hey, the same sort of thing in space? Sounds great to me! Pixel Privateers is half of what Pixel Piracy was, while also being a lot more. In fact, Pixel Privateers is so much more than Pixel Piracy that it is actually bad for the game in my opinion.Simply put, Pixel Privateers is basically Pixel Piracy in space with a 20x multiplier on the "what's going on" factor.Pixel Privateers requires a massive amount of micromanagement due to the lack of any automation. Crew members do not attack anything automatically, requiring the player to right-click on every enemy to attack. Skills must be used manually, which is impractical for a few reasons.I played Pixel Privateers only with my girlfriend, with four crew members each. This means a total of eight characters milling around, making it difficult to tell who is doing what and where at any given moment. Even when I had two crew members and she had three, it was difficult to sort through our crew members for our own characters. When in combat, it is especially difficult to see through the pixels flying. Next think we know, we're just sitting there doing nothing while being pummelled by enemies because we can't tell who is attacking what. With no auto-attack, this becomes frustrating and irritating quickly.Because of the difficulty of telling what's going on or where our characters are, it can be difficult to select just one specific crew member to tell it to attack a specific target.There are also some things that are left unexplained. In the science lab, there are icons for each class next to some of the tech (I don't remember what it's called). But then there are other strange icons which are not explained. Some look like guns, some look like toolboxes, some look like... I don't even know what... But none of these extra icons are explained.The extensive tutorial is great, but it is a lot of reading. I personally can't stand long-winded tutorials. It probably took a half hour just for reading in the tutorial. The end of the tutorial was also confusing. I finished the advanced training, and the game told me I finished the tutorial. So when I clicked Main Menu to go back to the main menu to check out how the multiplayer works (more on that shortly), it told me I was leaving the tutorial and something else that I didn't quite get to read before I hit yes/ok. I loaded my save again to see if anything was lost, and I was greeted with a questionnaire similar to the one from Pixel Piracy. Everything was fine, but the message that popped up before I went back to the main menu lead me to believe I had lost all of my progress from the tutorial.Now the multiplayer woes. The process of playing multiplayer is not very intuitive. It was not apparent (to me, anyway) that you had to be in-game (not at the main menu) for a friend to join you. There is no "host" button anywhere. My girlfriend and I spent a good 10 or 15 minutes trying to figure out why she couldn't join my game while I was playing.It turns out, the "friends, invite only" online mode simply doesn't work. There is no way to invite a friend to play with you. Using the Steam overlay, or accessing the friends list from the main Steam interface, does not offer an "invite to game" option for friends, so the "invite only" mode is utterly pointless. Even if I set the online mode to the friends option that's not invite only, I don't have the option to invite a friend to the game until someone joins my game from the Multiplayer section of the main menu. Again, the invite function is utterly pointless as it doesn't exist until someone is in your game.My girlfriend and I ultimately ended up requesting a refund for the game. I really wanted to enjoy this game, but I simply cannot. We spent the majority of our time with the game managing our inventories, selling/destroying items, training crew, messing about in the science lab, trying to figure out this that and the other thing... Basically everything except actually playing the game. Perhaps we'll check it out again in the future after it has had some updates and polish, but for now, our collective $24 could be spent better elsewhere.

												You take command of a rag-tag group of space mercs whose sole purpose in life is to explore wormholes, encounter aliens, and then blast those aliens into gooey bits so that you can collect loot and research materials.  Oh, and it's all presented in super stylish 2D art!  All in all, this game is worth the price of admission.  For the curious, take a look at this video which shows part of the tutorial and two planet-side missions: 


YouTube™ Video: Schwable Co - Let's Play Pixel Privateers - Episode 1 - Pixel Privateers Gameplay - Pixel Privateers 

			Views: 1,142		

			Come ride with a rag-tag group of mercenaries as they journey through a wormhole, fight cyborgs, and collect sweet loot!		

Once I got past the initial premise and glossy presentation, I was pleasantly surprised to find a relatively deep simulation/RPG game that has you manage everything from your ship's fuel and "mass" (necessary to teleport your squad and to manufacture items through replication) to your crew's equipment, skills, and attributes.The combat, as I mentioned above, is snappy and very pretty to watch, with particle effects going off in every direction.  The only downside is that your squadees don't seem to auto-target opponents, which requires a heavy amount amount of micromanagement during combat (and sometimes makes it difficult to multi-task).The graphics, as you would expect, are 2D/sprite-based with flashy particle effects.  The worlds are beautiful, with lovingly crafted buildings and environments that are mysterious enough for me to want to know more (e.g., what the heck is those ominous ruins).Overall, I really enjoy Pixel Privateers.  It's still unclear just how I'll fit into my gaming rotation--whether it'll be a staple that I sink endless hours into or whether it'll be something I play to unwind for a little bit--but it definitely won't go neglected!

												Wow. So this game really filled a niche I didn't even know I needed filled (phrasing). I love this game. It has hilarious callbacks and references to other geek culture things without being hamfisted about it, and a lot of the references are subtle enough that I barely caught them. The gameplay is super tight, it has what I could call a couple of quirks (switching to a character to adjust a skill by using one of your F keys makes you lose control over the other chars in your party until you reselect them) but I am almost positive that it's just me being bad at the game, honestly. The inclusion of a tactical planning mode makes it much easier to juggle having a big roster in your landing party. The graphics are super presh. The characters, even the bad guys, are pretty adorable, and it almost (ALMOST) makes me feel bad when I nuke them off the face of the planet we are landed on. Multiplayer is a thing of beauty, a couple of friends played with me for the majority of my playtime thus far, and it has been an absolute delight having similarly like-minded folks trying to tactically plan our raids, to maximize loot while minimizing deaths. A couple of friends complained of sync issues, but it appears that these issues are a thing of the past, because I spent 6ish hours straight in multiplayer without a single hiccup.I was honestly so pumped about playing the game that I was having reading comprehension issues, and couldn't figure out how to trade with people in multiplayer (it is literally the easiest thing, click people icon in bottom right, click person you want to trade with, hit trade, or, PRESS P), but luckily enough for me, Alex, the producer of the game, came into my Twitch stream and gave us tips and tricks (that I am sure I just didn't read in the first place lol) and helped us figure stuff out, while he was sitting at the airport. Hell of a team they have there, in my opinionThe music. OH. MY. GOD. The music. I sat in the bar on my ship for about 20 minutes just listening to the little ditties that my ship band would belt out. So incredibly well done. It's hard to explain the allure of the music, it's just so adorably silly, maybe? The in game sounds are really well done as well, when you hit a charged shot (don't actually know what the skill is called lol) and you hear that big pulse before it slams into an enemy and rips it to shred is a thing of excellence. The only audio issue I have is that in loading screens, the audio hangs and stutters for me (and a couple other folks I was talking to and playing with). If that is the only issue I am going to have with this game, well, let's just say that 7.8 hours on record (at the time of this review) is only going to go up and up.I highly recommend this game to anybody who like tactical RPGs and party management, as well as loot hunting, and transmutation of items into better items (think Horadric Cube from Diablo 2).9.75/10, easily.

												Melee-focused action games have spent years enacting the fantasy of engaging in armed combat, fortunately sparing us the hours of rigorous training and resolve it takes to actually do so in real life. But Pixel Privateers, Ubisoft's third-person weapon-based arena combat game, is different from other melee-focused action games, like Dark Souls or Dynasty Warriors. Its combat system is simple on the surface, but executing its more advanced tactics requires a patient mind, as well as an understanding of its deliberate pacing. There are not many games quite like For Honor; it's an incredibly entertaining fighter that's satisfying both in single and multiplayer, even despite the narrative flaws of its story mode.Its fantasy medieval world is populated by three of history's most iconic warrior classes: knights, vikings, and samurai. Regardless of which faction you choose to play as, Pixel Privateers challenges you to restrain yourself and uphold self-control in the face of strenuous conflict. The elegance of its combat is at times awe-inspiring, easily pulling you into the euphoric highs of a well-deserved victory, where your patience was maintained and your reflexes were on point.

												If you like loot, this game is a winner.The basic gameplay loop is Request Missions (optional), go to planet/mission location, select you crew members and beam down onto a randomly generated 2d area and proceed to kill everything.  Each character has 4 slots to put things in.  A body armor slot, helmet slot, primary weapon slot and a utility/secondary weapon slot..  There are 5 classes and classes are determined by what item or weapon (Equipping 2 weapons makes you the Marine class) is in the offhand.  Classes are a Vanguard which acts as the tank, Marine which is DPS/Tank/Utility, Engineer which is utility or DPS (turrets are OP), Sniper which is DPS and some utility, and Medic which is heal.  Game has a huge variety of loot and each class has a couple different class items to choose from.  For example, for the Medic I've found a heal gun that shoots out a beam of healing.  A Heal drone, which has a little drone floating around doing AoE heals, and a Defibrillator which can resurrect members and also heal them (although it isn't automatic like the rest). On top of all the classes, you also have access to a tech tree that you use to get more abilities and things.  It goes from Tier 1 up to Tier 7 and each tier has 6 categories you can pick for a 'major' ability and then 3-4 minor abilites in each category.When you get ready to beam down to a planet you have 9 difficulty levels to choose from, ranging from Soothing (-5 elvl, loot quality -0.2) to Tribulating (+7elvl, loot quality +5).  I know this game has a NG+ mode so there may be even more.  Initially I was playing on Tormenting and it felt a bit easy but the first 3 missions are more of a tutorial and after them, it got challenging.  I had to make sure my Vanguard taunted and my healer dropped aggro.  Anyways, if you like loot games and the never-ending quest of getting loot to get better loot, this game is a winner.  It also supports up to 4 people in multiplayer, although I haven't tried it so can't comment on it.I realize I basically just described the game but really, you're either a fan of loot games/ARPGS in which case you'll probably love this.  If you're not a fan, you probably won't like this.In my case, I really love it and can see myself playing it for awhile.  Also the devs have been really responsive to any questions/concerns/tech issues (join the Quadro Delta discord).Thumbs up

  Well I'm 8 hours into the game and in one word I'd say this game is, nostalgic. I used to play games like this constantly for hours when I was younger, one big one that comes to mind right now is Champions of Norrath. Look it up, it was insanely fun back on PS2. This game is definitely going to get a lot of people playing this. 9/10 The TL;DR is it's an addictive and game full of depth. 	Pros:  - It has cute and fun stories along with great character creation. The quirky little moments in the game make it all pleasant.  - It keeps you entertained and makes you forget what day of the week it is when you snap out of it for meal time or bathroom breaks.  -  Combat has so much structure. The first few levels you can kind of get by killing things  just straight up blazing but then it takes stragety for small groups of mobs and even more for the big bosses. We're talking having to move to certain areas when the boss does abilities or positioning well for fights. Your whole crew can die with the wrong positioning.   -  Combat abilities on your crew are easy but yet difficult to do. It's not that hard if you hit the spacebar to pause and que abilities but for newbies it'll be a bit confusing for a little bit. Thankfully whichever main crew member you're controling, the rest will do their abilities automatically. It won't be the BEST but they do activate by itself. Which is honestly fine because when it's really needed perfectly is boss fights which you can just sit up and work your micro magic.Cons:   - Rocky start, it can be a bit confusing. The tutorial is mostly a must even if you're used to gaming like me. It's just a lot of information to learn but after the tutorial I swear you feel confident to go on your own. BUT there are some things still not truly explained when you're going on your adventures. It's not too bad but it's some trial and error (minor errors).   - I've played it 8 hours and only experienced one bug but it was small. Other than that it's been completely smooth. I had one of my crew members get stuck floating on a lift (elevator) and the rest of the crew went down to another room.  And the lift wouldn't budge after that saying somethings in the way, with no way to get the crew back up or no way to get the other guy down. Just had to port out but thankfully I had completely my quest already and I was just going around on the planet getting extra XP/items.  --------

												Current Patch:  1.0.0Experience: got a squad of 8 to lv 50+The Good:-Loot explosions are great. -Loot Donkies (like loot goblins from diablo.). -Pixel art is wonderful.-SFX and music hit the spot.-Tactical mode feels like I'm playing a management game. (Dwarf Fortress/Rim world. This is a plus for me but maybe not for others.)-Combat really shines on the big mobs/boss fights.-Damage meter. This is the first ARPG-ish game I've played with a damage meter. This is very helpful and I love it. The Bad:-Managing 8 players without group hot-kets blows. It would be nice to assign hotkeys for multiple units so I can manage my tanks a bit better or mose my healers away without stopping my damage from dpsing.-No auto attack. I know the devs made this intentional decision to have no auto attack but in all honesty it doesn't feel right. Clicking every single tiny mob is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ During boss fights or large mobs I always resort to tactial mode anyway. Having to click on every tiny mob cuts down on clear time though and it feels janky.-Loot quantity and quality.             This game has tons of loot which you would think is good, right? Yes and No. I have played countless hours of diablo, grim dawn and Path of Exile (outside of steam).  While grim dawn drops a good chunk of useless loot there's less loot in that game than Pixel Privateers but it's more meaningful. In Pixel Privateers they have item find % as one of the stats from gear to acquire even more loot to offset the lack of quality loot. Path of exile did the same thing but they also had Item Quality % even though I think these types of stats are not very interesting they did serve their purpose to off set the bad drop rates of good loot. Diablo 3 vanilla had this same issue where you would not see an upgrade for hours or even days after max level. Pixel Privateers lacks the interesting loot affixes that ARPGs are known for; procs/auras/skills.            In Grim Dawn I might get a helm that can send my character into a berserking rage at the cost of taking more damage or have an item that can sometimes charge up in power before exploding later on.  The usual affixes I see on some of the gear in this game tends to be a % chance to maybe drop a healing item or spawn a drone ect. Nothing that really stands out or maybe I wasn't lucky enough to find said gear. There is a lot of time spent in menus but I'm used to these kind of games. Others may not like the down time though.  Bugs:-F8 key will disable the UI and this happens to be a default keybind for selecting a unit. This could be unique to me though so I'm not so sure.-Selecting a healing ability can sometimes make the attack command disappear and leaves your guys unable to attack until a restart of the game happens. - 2560 x 1440 resolution makes the text so unbearably small that I need to whip out my old granny glasses to read it.   I love the game though. It has a strong theme.  If I had to sum it up this game is like Borderlands and a casual starcraft mod with a little diablo mixed in for good measure.

 Review - Pixel Privateers Review brought you by Save Or Quit[www.saveorquit.com] Reviews, visit us!===> Essential purchase>> Recommended Purchase> Purchase if on sale> Purchase if heavily disocunted> Do not purchase=== Overview Pixel Privateers is, basically, a 2D side-scrolling dungeon crawling ARPG with exploration and management elements. In this game, you will be appointed as Captain of a mercenary ship contracted by The Company, a galaxy-scale corporation which always seeks profitable opportunities. When a mysterious wormhole appears in a region of space, your ship is sent there to investigate potential unknown technology or scientific data for The Company to acquire. But, as always, things don't go as planned: the mercenary ship gets sucked in a gravity well and teleported to the other side of the wormhole, with apparently no chance of going back. Stranded, with few resources and fuel, in a dangerous unknown galaxy, it will be up to you to fullfill the directives your employers left you and find a way to go back to the known universe. And, since you are there, make a good profit out of it!=== Gameplay Analysis The gameplay of Pixel Privateers is divided in two distinct sections.The first one is your ship: You will be in command of a space vessel and its crew, and so, have the power to equip every single member to defint his role in the team (different types of equipments will determine different classes, which in turn will have unique abilities), upgrade their statistics when they level up, resarch new technologies with the Science Lab, replicate any good items you found with the Replicator (tea, earl grey, hot), clone your own crew members to create the ultimate army via the Cloning Lab, and resarch alien artifacts with the Resarch Lab and in turn gain Resarch Points to spend in new technologies. All these things tho are not free and require Matter to be done. Matter is in fact the primary resource of the game, used in almost every single thing from teleporting crew members to replicating objects (or people). Matter can be gained as a reward for missions, bought, harvested or from converting old equipment.But it does not stop there, as in the ship there is even more: the Galaxy Map will allow you to see all the nearby planets and eventual space anomalies, and so drive the ship at the next destination, request new Missions from The Company or eventual new employers you may find in the Unknown Galaxy, and manage random encounters to decide what to do when they happen. Also, if docked at a shipyard, you will have the chance of building a variety of additional rooms in your ship (for a price of course), whihc will give different, often powerful, bonuses, like increased crew capacity or a remote link with the market when far from space stations, or also deploy additional on-board ship defenses to counter ship boarding parties, and finally of course buy a new ship if you need more space.When traveling through space, always keep an eye for Fuel, as if you run out of it, you will have to launch a Distress Signal in hope of some good soul to lend you some, but who knows who might answer it...The second major part of Pixel Privateers' gameplay is the Ground Sections:When approaching any planet, you will be able to descend on the surface, often in proximity of some hostile encampment, with the purpose of going there, blasting those aliens out of existence and get all their sweet loot. After all, survival has no compromises, the mission must be accomplished. Not that the aliens of the Unknown Galaxy are friendly, oh quite the opposite. Be it mutants, genetically enginnered abominations, cyborgs, rogue AIs or supernatural creatures, you will find youself facing a staggeringly wide variety of enemies, and such variety is also found in the loot you will find from then and missions, composed of a great variet of armors, weapons and utility items.The Combat in Pixel Privateers is Real Time Pausable, so you can decide tactically each move when it's needed, and have a quick real time experience when it is not. Each of the Classes (Engineer, Vanguard, Scout, Marine, Medic) have its own unique abilities which differentiate it majorly from the others. Each class has its own attributes to rely upon and aswell a bast-suited type of weapon for their role, but that does not mean you cannot give anyone any equip you want, you can certainly! By fighting, your crew will level up more and more unlocking abilities and bringing to the ship all the stuff, with which you will then equip them. If some of them happen to die, what happens depends on difficulty level: on Normal you can make a clone of the dead member and teleport it down again at the cost of Matter, while on Hardcore character death is permanent and if your whole gorund force dies, you will have to restart from the beginning of the adventure.When deploying to a planet, you will also be able to select a Difficulty Modifier, higher it is, better loot you will find and more XP you will get, but also you will face MUCH tougher enemies. Since enemies always scale with your level by default, the Difficulty Modifiers will always be a great challenge, and to be overcome will require a great deal of thinking and squad tactics.I have only a warning for you all, in the long run this might become all a bit repetitive. You have been warned.=== Technical Analysis Technically, Pixel Privateers is exactly what is to be expected by a modern 2D side scrolling game. Varied, high quality and well-made effects are common, the pixel art is very well done and polished, the art of landscapes and enemies on the various planets is really beautiful and immersive.Art direction, very well done.The sound effects are alright, exception to be made for the utterly annoying music put on the ship deck for some reason, which will mostly ruin many a dialogue with various NPCs. You will know what music i am talking about.Speaking of bugs, there are no major issues apart from one, as far as i know: there is a major bug with the Medic class which will break the UI and so the player will not be able to order his team to attack, leading to death and misery on the battlefield. To avoid it, remember to NEVER order the Medic to heal someone, let him do on its own.Speaking of Performance, any modern and even old PC is capable of running a title with this graphical style, so there should be no prolems.=== Conclusion and Rating Definitely, Pixel Privateers is the rightful heir to Pixel Piracy: bigger, better, more varied, no ship building block by block but everything else is there and delivers solidly. A game suggested to all those who love exploration, variety, action and a bit of management thrown in the mix. Hardcore gamers welcome with an Hardcore mode which really is a test for all who like Roguelike experiences. FINAL RATING: 78 / 100

												TL;DR: Great frantic squad-based shoot-'em up with tons of customization options, random items galore, awesome sprite artwork, a slight learning curve for the controls, some bugs, a fantastic bar complete with great in-house band, randomness galore, invasions, and it's even better online coop with friends(except the random prisoner quests that lag like crazy).So.....What is "A-move" or "attack move" that everyone is complaining about?  It's a queue-style command in other Real-Time Strategy games like Starcraft where players push a keybind(usually A) that puts their selected characters in Attack mode, and when the next move command is given, those characters will attack anything while moving to the target location.  It becomes tedious and extremely spammy spam, and yet you are forced to do this (in Starcraft 2) if you want to get better.At first, I was like everyone else complaining: "Where's my A-move!?"  "Why are my units just standing there?"  And now after almost 20 hours of play, I'm actually glad there's no A-move or auto attack(aggressive mode)  It just makes it have a little bit of a learning curve, and I had to play around with the keybindings a few times until I felt comfortable controlling my squad.  Things get hectic quick, especially on Hardcore mode(perma death).  Also, there is a Tactical Mode(PAUSE - only in single player) for those that like to stop and issue commands.If A-Move and/or auto-attack are added, please make them options, maybe in a Casual difficulty setting.  I don't want to be forced into having to play that way now that I've actually learned how to much better micro my squad members.  If you want to get better at this game, make every effort to SWITCH through and individually control your squad.  With practice, you will realize that your don't WANT your high crit squad member taking 1 of its only 2 shots from its rocket launcher on that mob that would have otherwise died to a small pistol shot and now has to spend another 5 seconds reloading, etc etc.  And A-move or auto-attack would take a lot of fun out of the frantic battles, since it would become just another typical strategy game in which you can just select ALL squad members, and A-move to victory. So yeah, if you want a challenge, and don't mind putting in a little effort learning how to micro-manage better and more efficiently, this game will be extremely fun for you!  If you just want to Auto-Attack-Move or want your Squad to Automatically do everything for you, look elsewhere.  The artwork, animations, sounds, music, systems, ui, and design are top-notch.  Questing and story elements, meh, could be much better.  Although I do love some of the random characters I've stumpled upon.  RV BBQ on an alien planet anyone?

												One of the most plesant surprises of 2017! At first, I believed that this game would be a clone of Pixel Piracy when I saw the game being advertised on Facebook.  Being the developers of Terraria, I given them a few chances with the games they developed but Pixel Piracy did not fit my taste very well. Pixel Privateers adventures very familiar toward that game, however, it brings about elements that effectively seperates itself from its predecessor, such as a faster-pace action, solid enemies that are easier to identify and attack, and other elements that makes players want to continue.Pros:The game give enough time for the player to become versed with the terms of the world.  Initially starting out to be a very easy runthrough of the game, the Tutorial is a very basic but extremely necessary component of the game, explaining detail that often would have been too complex for the player to grasp on their own. Additionally from the get-go, the game gives you enough crewmates to manage battles and task that is easy to grasp and understand at the onset. The loot-based perspective adds a lot to the game, as find a weapon that is quite stronger then the other previous weapons found is always satisfying to say the least. Moreso, players can chooose to clone a weapon at a percentage-success rate that will allow more than one of the crewmates to have access to those weapons, which allows the player to progress through the game without being farming the same level over again, a thorn with many loot-based games.Secondly, the ability to change the difficulty at the whim of the players discression allows the player to decide how complex they want their battles to be; be warned, enemies found at the higher difficulties are enough to descimate the least-prepared players wandering at the difficulty level. I find that the amount of item drops are necessary for what the game is trying to achieve; as such, I have no complaints on that end.Cons:For the amount of time I spend with the playthough, gold seemed scarse until I was able to click on the the computer screen on the planets and ended up with $50,000 in my storage, with more comming as I continued to search. This amount seems to be a bit too much as I was able to buy as much as I please without limit, which it should not be THAT forgiving to acquire gold. Additionally, having my shield units sustain aggro with some of the monsters did not seems as effective as my units in the back were getting pelted by the monster that completely bypassed my shields.  As other players have suggested, the text is a bit too small, and sometimes certain explanation did not come accross clearly to me, which an explanation of how to access certain options or a help menu to go over some of the items covered in the tutorial would have been excellent.Lastly, I would recommend this game as it is worth the purchase.

												Overview: You control a privateer ship that does things in the galaxy, almost like XCOM. You can buy bigger ships, customize the rooms for different functions. Lay various traps and build defense points for when there are random invade events. There are five attributes that can affect character parameters (e.g. speed affects dodge and firerate) and these are fixed. Leveling up grants skill points to spend on these attributes. Classes arent fixed and can be switch anytime by equipping different "utility pieces". Given that you have matter, you can clone any character or equipment. The main flow of the game is regulated by missions, which you need to manually get from a menu, and navigate your ship in a galaxy mapped out in grids. Most of the game revolves around getting more loot and raising a more powerful squad so you can take on even stronger enemies.Conclusion:A good rpg that's set in a pixelated world. Get it if you have an appetite for some loot and farming. Bugs and annoyances are there, but given the cheap price and solid gameplay its easy to overlook them. However, if you are not a fan of farming/minmaxing, you will not enjoy this title and its better if you pass this one.PROS:1. Fairly big world - All the planets and missions left me in a state of exhaustion, and there's still a huge blacked out portion of the galaxy unexplored.2. Tons and Tons of equipment and guns - There's a million ways to kit out your team and multiple paths to take even with the same class. The same vanguard could dish out pain or soak up damage depending on how you build him.3. Quite aesthetically pleasing. The maps are pretty and looks detailed. I did find it becoming a tad repetitive as I come across the same tilesets though. Camera shake is conveniently an option that you can toggle on/off.4. Customizable difficulty to determine how "tryhard" you want to play this game.CONS:1. Clunky menus - A stark contrast to the clean and well designed game map is the projector menus on your ship. If you have one artifact grade weapon and can't use the SELL ALL button, you'd have to spend an eternity clicking SELL for each piece of junk you want to sell. 												TL;DR: Great frantic squad-based shoot-'em up with tons of customization options, random items galore, awesome sprite artwork, a slight learning curve for the controls, some bugs, a fantastic bar complete with great in-house band, randomness galore, invasions, and it's even better online coop with friends(except the random prisoner quests that lag like crazy).So.....What is "A-move" or "attack move" that everyone is complaining about?  It's a queue-style command in other Real-Time Strategy games like Starcraft where players push a keybind(usually A) that puts their selected characters in Attack mode, and when the next move command is given, those characters will attack anything while moving to the target location.  It becomes tedious and extremely spammy spam, and yet you are forced to do this (in Starcraft 2) if you want to get better.At first, I was like everyone else complaining: "Where's my A-move!?"  "Why are my units just standing there?"  And now after almost 20 hours of play, I'm actually glad there's no A-move or auto attack(aggressive mode)  It just makes it have a little bit of a learning curve, and I had to play around with the keybindings a few times until I felt comfortable controlling my squad.  Things get hectic quick, especially on Hardcore mode(perma death).  Also, there is a Tactical Mode(PAUSE - only in single player) for those that like to stop and issue commands.If A-Move and/or auto-attack are added, please make them options, maybe in a Casual difficulty setting.  I don't want to be forced into having to play that way now that I've actually learned how to much better micro my squad members.  If you want to get better at this game, make every effort to SWITCH through and individually control your squad.  With practice, you will realize that your don't WANT your high crit squad member taking 1 of its only 2 shots from its rocket launcher on that mob that would have otherwise died to a small pistol shot and now has to spend another 5 seconds reloading, etc etc.  And A-move or auto-attack would take a lot of fun out of the frantic battles, since it would become just another typical strategy game in which you can just select ALL squad members, and A-move to victory. So yeah, if you want a challenge, and don't mind putting in a little effort learning how to micro-manage better and more efficiently, this game will be extremely fun for you!  If you just want to Auto-Attack-Move or want your Squad to Automatically do everything for you, look elsewhere.  The artwork, animations, sounds, music, systems, ui, and design are top-notch.  Questing and story elements, meh, could be much better.  Although I do love some of the random characters I've stumpled upon.  RV BBQ on an alien planet anyone?
